Bottle from 16 Tons, Eugene. Pours exceptionally dark, moderate amount of tan head. Aroma rich and smooth, sweet with oat and Bourbon coming to te forefront. Rich, dense, chocolate. Body medium-lively, finish rich in coffee, chocolate, vanilla. This is really nice, if a bit sweet now. Will be interested to see how it ages.

Bottle; Pour is murky dark brown, with a modest, fine bubbled khaki colored head into this glass; it retains on the average side, with light lacing present here. The nose is initial roast, coffee bean and espresso, with a hint of vanilla here. Earth comes through with a touch of chocolate, wrapping it up fairly nicely. The flavor profile is initial chocolate morsels, moving to earthen oaked notes which provide a certain bittering effect - mild fruit comes through, moving to vanilla and more roasted coffee bean here - what Im barely getting is any bourbon treatment from this brew ; it still retains some of its modesty from the oatmeal stout base and comes out as a more complex, somewhat boring version by my estimation -

Bomber in the mountains in Breckenridge with Taylor. Pours coffee black with thick creamy head that drops to a thin film. Aroma is bourbon, roasted coffee, raw oaks, big burnt malt, Carmel, cocoa powder. Taste is silky smooth, complex toffee and roasted malt with bourbon, slightly boozy on the end in a nice way.

Bottle from Gentiles Chicago. Poured almost black brown with fine tan head. Decent vanilla bourbon aroma that hangs in my nose. Light carb and med bod. Can tell its an oatmeal stout base. Not hot at all. As it warms it improves becoming silkier with some smoke. Well done.

Strong aromas of vanilla, rum, oak wood, bourbon, tropical fruits, cinnamon and roasted toffee. The aroma alone is unreal. Solid black appearance, much like that of an 8-ball. Thin foam rim. Incredible balance with slick caramel, molasses and black malts upfront with a secondary phase of maple, toffee, toasted sugar, candied caramel and sweet, dark fruits. Strong bourbon notes on the finish yet, the alcohol is not even detectable. Overall, this is one of the most balanced beers I have ever experienced. Very smooth and drinkable with uniform complexity. Id give this an A+ rating.

12 ounce pour at Hopleaf in Chicago. I was surprised to find this one locally...such a great name. The aroma delivers as promised, featuring easily accessible oak, bourbon, vanilla, and oatmeal creaminess. Black liquid, low carbonation, low levels of foam. It tastes amazing. Again. vanilla, oats, chocolate, vanilla, and a balanced bourbon edge that piques your senses. This would absolutely go with brunch food, especially sausage. The woodsiness provides a muted, understated tone that makes it so smooth. Velvety and thick bodied. Overall excellent.

so, this goes in the right direction. I got the last bottle tonight and watched Caddyshack (a good pairing). Now, the nose goes to the sweet heavy alch alley, and the light brown tea reading clouds lace the pond of translucent black. The mouthfeel is light for this type of beer, so swishing it in my mouth was helpful. But being in the Bourbon-barrel aged catagory, it leaves me a bit underwhelemed in the company of KBS and BCBS, and Boris the Crusher. But I was able to get throught the bottle without zonking out.
22 oz bottle shared. Black/brown with a tan head. Wood, vanilla, dark fruit, roast, milk chocolate, medium sweetness.

22 ounce bottle purchased at The Davis Beer Shoppe. The aroma on this is gorgeous, with sweet hints of chocolate and plenty of woody, bourbon characteristics. Vanilla is also present. Amazing aroma. Opaque dark mahogany body with a small, fairly quickly dissipating light tan head present. Starts a little sweet with some cocoa notes, before some bourbon and oaky flavors come through in the middle. Finishes with some vanilla flavor. Very mellow, extremely easy-drinking, and so incredibly decadent. So fucking good.

Bottle. Pours deep brown, nearly black with thick, creamy tan head of nice duration, splotchy lacing. Aroma is big on the chocolate, vanilla, and oak. Throw in some firestone walker je ne sais quoi, and you have an inviting beer. Taste is moderately sweet, with milk chocolate, more vanilla, and a pleasant roasty, almost charred finish. Caramel and toffee as well. Texture is thin on this, which is a shame. I understand its not an imperial stout, but it otherwise presents itself as one. Anyway, medium body, thin, slick texture, soft carbonation, dry finish leaves me feeling almost parched. Plenty of bourbon / alcohol present in all phases as well. Overall: this is very nice, but mouthfeel is its weak point. FW is perhaps victim to its own success in this regard, as the proprietor barrel-aged and boxed series is the height of richness and intensity, leading, perhaps, to unrealistic subconscious expectations.

22, capped, foiled, and boxed attractively. Pours a very, very dark ebony, just shy of black. Fizzy tan head that settles to a creamy disc and sticks around for a while. Fairly mild nose, blending sweet milk chocolate, roasted malt, toasty grain husks, and a bit of vanilla. Creamy medium body with soft carb. Chocolate, vanilla, toasty malt notes, and a bit of wood on the mid palate. Mild sweet finish.

Bottle poured into a tulip; Id been waiting to try this one. Pours clear black with small tan head. Nose is bourbon, oak, vanilla, roast. Overall a disappointment for sure - reminded me some of Bruery Ebony and Oak - just not what a BA stout is supposed to be.

Bottle from around town. Aroma and flavor of light bourbon and thinner oatmeal stout. I really feel like the base beer was too modest to stand up to an aging. Great beer for blending the anniversary series, otherwise it's not worth the money...maybe $8, rather than $15. Ok beer.

Nice pour. Big bourbon on nose with cocoa and tobacco. Taste is thin watery and really dry. Bourbon is the only flavor that lingers. Pours black with tan head. Aroma is of sweet, cocoa, spicy bourbon. Palate is where it needs to be but it is overwhelmingly sweet. So much that it takes over, not in a good way. Maybe some aging to help this?

This is actually a much lighter stout than I had thought. The bourbon definitely comes through with a strong flavor, but not alcohol, leaving an anise-like warmth on the tongue. A good stout with lots of character.

On draft at Firestone Walker Buellton, CA. I can taste the greatness in this beer and I can see how it won two golds at GABF, but the pour I got seemed lacking. On tap at bier 30 firestone night. Pours out black topped with a tan head. Great nose of burb roast malts sweetness and chocolate. Taste is more of the burb malts light bitter sweetness and some abv. A little thin but overall pretty good.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2013 Draft at 12 FOBAB, this was the disapointment of the day. Very thin, lacked any noticible bourbon flavor. Maybe it was because i had been drinking much stronger bourbon aged stouts all day but i couldnt taste anything. 



Retried, this time with the bottle, batch 1.  Still not very impressed.  Decent bourbon flavor with no burn.  Flavors are very subdued.  Creamy yet thin mouthfeel.  Not worth buying at this price.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2014 Draught from Brouwerij Lane.  Just a little light shines through on the dark brown with ok head & lace.  The aroma is bourbon, chocolate sweetness, light roast, wood. Darft on tap at Twisted Spoke (Chicago, IL). Pours a deep blackish brown hue, good opaque quality, frothy light brown head atop dies to a film, laces ok. Some brown glow on the bottom and edges. Starts out great with a soft, malty nose. A clear black pour with a fast fading head. Soft palate again that borders on faint and unspeaking.

Clear deep dark brown, with a delicious sweet aroma of chocolate, coconut, bourbon-oak, vanilla, graham cracker, and sugar cane. Flavor was semi-full bodied with a solid dark flavor that lingered a log time. Roast and toasted malts greet the flavor, quickly turning to coconut and toasted chocolate, finishing with oak, chocolate, and vanilla with a long finish of bourbon-like tannins.

Opaque black with a small, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malts, cocoa, vanilla, whiskey, lactose, and burnt wood. Taste of vanilla, roasted malts, cocoa, burnt wood, marshmallow, and whiskey.
For such a hyped-up beer of a beloved brewery of mine I was expecting far better. Slightly thin, complexity isnt there for me.
Sampled at Falling Rock.  Pours an oily opaque black.  Nose is boozy, sweet, coconut milk, chocolate.  Sweet flavor, cake icing, caramel, booze, vanilla.  Full, sweet finish.  Really nice.
Draft. Pours near black with a beige head. Light roasted malts, bourbon, dark chocolate, dark fruits, and lighter noted of coffee and vanilla. Solid.
Had this at the 2012 Great American Beer Fest in Denver, Colorado. Great barrel scent, bit of chocolate, taste is similar with a great wood roast flavor.

The appearance is deep black, light tan head.  The aroma is bourbon, chocolate, licorice.  The flavor is the exact same.  The fnish is sweet, bourbon.  Medium/thick in body, creamy mouthfeel.  Very nice.
tap at Barcade: Chocolate & dark fruit. Raspberry malts & caramel some nuttiness. Tasty biit sweet. Boozy finish. interesting.

On tap at barcade. Incredible aroma of chocolate and bourbon--not super strong, just well balanced.

Firestone 100% Barrel-aged Velvet Merlin 5/10/12 notes: draft. Pours thicker than usual, deep dark brown. Aroma and flavor hold much rich chocolate, some toasted oat sweet graininess, bits of mocha. This version has a heftier body, more chocolate and general decadence than the original; both are fantastic.

Draft. Black beer with a light tan head. Bourbon and chocolate aroma. Bourbon and chocolate flavor with light caramel. Medium-plus bodied. Bourbon and chocolate lingers with light caramel and a light nuttiness.

Draft at Varga Bar in Philadelphia, PA. 

Pours a dark brown, almost black color with a one finger light beige head that slowly settles into a lasting ring. Sporadic streaks of lace left behind. 

Boozy bourbon barrel aroma thats nicely integrated into the base beer(which is partially bourbon BA). I thought amping it up to 100% BA might kill off some of those notes but theyre still there underneath the barrel presence. Strong spicy bourbon, earthy oak, vanilla and coconut followed by roasted dark malt, chocolate, robust coffee and oatmeal. 

Medium bodied but a bit thinner than I expected with a strong bourbon barrel presence thats excellently integrated into the flavor of the regular Merlin version. Sweet and spicy bourbon dominated up front with some boozy heat but it never becomes to hot. Feels stronger than 8.6 but not harsh. Theres also some dry oak, toasted coconut and vanilla followed by roasted dark malt, silky chocolate, caramel, toffee and oatmeal. Subtle dry bitterness but never approaches burnt or acrid. Really well balanced and although there is a decent amount of heat its very easy to drink.
Cask. Pours cola with a tan head. Good retention/little lace. Aroma of vanilla, chocolate, coffee, roast. Taste is bakers chocolate, vanilla, drip coffee. Mouthfeel is dry, watery, soft carbonation.

First pour from the cask conditioned version, courtesy of Greg at Paradiso Dupont, thank you sir!  Extremely dark maroon color, massive beige head, nice lacing. Aroma of vanilla, milk chocolate, dark fruit. Taste is smokey burnt cocoa, burnt espresso, vanilla. Really nice.
Charred beef, slightly smoky aroma.Cola black, medium yellow head. A little thin.  Charred oak flavor, hints of meat. No bourbon at all. Soft carbonation. A little disappointed, but it is enjoyable.

Tap @ FWIBF. Pours a black color with a beige head. Aroma is of roasted malt, oaty sweetness, bourbon, oak, sweet chocolate, vanilla, lactose like flavors and coffee. Flavor follows the nose with lots of bourbon and vanilla, some oak, coconut, liquorice,  sweet chocolate and coffee. The body is full with a creamy mouth feel. Overall a really nice version of Velvet Merlin!

Draught at TND:  Aroma of Bourbon, oak, chocolate, vanilla, and some coconut.  Poured very dark brown/ruby in color with a large, creamy, dense, brown head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Clear.  Slightly sparkling.  Flavor is medium sweet.  Tastes of malt, Bourbon, cream, vanilla, coconut, and some wood.  Medium body.  Slicky, creamy texture.  Soft carbonation.  Malt, Bourbon, cream, vanilla, coconut, and some wood in the sweet, slick finish.

Draft at Churchkey after the FW dinner. Pours an opaque black with small, creamy beige head. Nose is actually not impressive, with big yogurt and weird fruity bourbon notes. The flavor lends itself more to what I think this beer should be, with gorgeous lactic smoothness, milky flavor mixed with bourbon vanilla sweetness. Definitely inferior to FWXV as far as Im concerned, but still tasty and worth a try.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2013 Aroma of French vanilla coffee.  Pours black with small blonde head.   Taste is marshmallow, roast coffee and heavy cream.

re-rate
Taste has more licorice depth with a creamy marshmallow and toffee taste.  Better than remembered.

Pours black with a thin tan head that leaves lacing. Aroma is roasty & sweet at the same time. Taste is sweet chocolate & immensely smooth. Its actually fairly light in body while being very flavorful. Extremely drinkable at 8+%. Very, very good!

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2013 Draft. Dark pour. Big, big, big vanilla bourbon flavors. Sweet dark caramel. Fantastically smooth. Deep. Rich. Clean. Syrupy but not overly thick. Excellent! Update - Just an add but the winter 2013 merkin is fantastic!

Tap at brewery.  Black pour with a thin scatter of tan foam.  Aroma is bourbon, oak, minor vanilla, some alcohol heat, and underlying roast.  Taste is heavy bourbon with vanilla and an almost sweet cola flavor followed by roast, chocolate, and hop/alcohol bitterness on the finish.  Mouthfeel is a bit light but appropriate.  The barrel character is semi-hot and dominates the base beer but it works.  Great barrel aged beer in the sub-10% abv range.

Aroma of vanilla and bourbon, smells great. Black oil looking, a nice looking beer.   Tastes Of vanilla and bourbon, but its very well done. I really like this beer! It should be a little difficult to drink, BUT its very easy to drink. A great beer
Draft.  Clear rudy dark brown, tin light tan head.  Chocolate, sweetness, vanilla, bourbon, and milk chocolate.  A very nice dessert beer, on the sweet side.  Close to imperial status.

Black pour thin off white head orange hue ...... Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, light oak and caramel malts .... Taste is dry, oaky, caramel malts. vanilla.  Earthy, thin roasted light chocolate and tasty. ... Lots of dry oak. A sessionable very well done medium bodied oatmeal stout. Mouthfeel is slick and oily  ...  Abv hidden well

On tap at Daily Pint.  Pours a brown color with white foam head.  Sweet light caramel taste with some chocolate notes hidden somewhere and slight bitters.  Has a chalky mouthfeel.  Solid but was expecting a bit more.

Dark brown pour with a small tan head.  The aroma reminds me of chocolate milk with a little bit of vanilla added to it.  Minimal roast and coffee notes, just an overwhelming chocolate/vanilla blend.  Great barrel and bourbon flavor with even more of the chocolate and vanilla going on.  Moderate roast and a hint of coffee.  Nicely sweet from some toffee malt flavors.  So damn good.

Tap @ Bruery Provisions. Smells like barrel aged stout, not over powering. Taste is phenomenal. Some earthiness, some licorice, some malt, some alcohol, some barrel - incredibly balanced. Pours opaque, nearly jet black with tan head. Long lasting palate that just lingers and lingers...

UPDATED: APR 6, 2012 Draft at Spuytin with Andrew. Pours a deep black body with thin brown lacing. Aroma is sweet chocolate and and very light coffee. Mouthfeel is thin and a bit watery with notes of coffee, coconut, bourbon and chocolate.
Tap at Browerij Lane.  Boozy sweet nose. Vanilla , bourbon booze , more bourbon. Dry delicious dessert like. Awesome

On tap at the brewery. Finally was in town when they had this one on tap.  Pours a blackish color with tan head.  Aroma is bourbon, vanilla, coconut and slight cherry.  Taste is outstanding as I really didnt think I would enjoy this one as much as I did.  More chocolate comes through but huge notes of coconut which really, really works in a stout. Overall, this very well could be my favorite stout of all time and that is from someone who really doesnt enjoy this style. (Thus take that as you will.) I could go for a glass of this every few months.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: UPDATED: OCT 21, 2013 Tap @ Tap n Handle. Im excited as fuck to finally try this as I love the standard version. Deep brown/black appearance with a tan head. A bit boozy, somewhat sharp bourbon, toasty oak, vanilla, toasty, caramel malty, dark chocolate, very rich coconut aroma. Huge coconut, rich, fairly boozy bourbon, toffee, dark chocolate, very oaky flavor with a pretty boozy finish. The bourbon is overdone on this one and makes it a bit hard to drink. Its tasty nonetheless, just overdone. Re-rate from bottle: a bit thin, light watery, kind of boozy but tasty nonetheless.

Tap @ Star Bar, Denver. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, bourbon, caramel, dark fruit. Taste is malts, coffee, caramel, bourbon, vanilla, oak, hints of dark fruit. Medium body, soft carbonation. Very nice, again very easy drinking. 040312

Furkin love it.  Good stuff.  I was lucky enough to talk to the rep early on in the Sac Brewers Showcase at like 1pm.  We got to talking and he explained the old school velvet pubes and whatnot.  Hilarious.  Love it.  Ok, so this beer was creamy, malty, smooth, rich, dark, lightly hopped, and overall O-mazing.  I could float the keg, after a taste I was hooked.  Good stuff. Man i wish I lived closer to FW.

On tap at Homemade Liquids and Solids poured a clear dark reddish brown with a small lingering tan head. Aromas of bourbon, oak, dark chocolate, vanilla, roastiness and light coffee. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of bourbon, oak, dark chocolate, light vanilla and light roastiness withg a smooth lingering chocolatey bourbon finish.

The aroma is full of bourbon notes yet the velvet Merlins traditional coffee notes still come through in abundance. The appearance is typical of a stout. Taste is what I believe velvet Merlin should taste like in the first place. It is a wonderful beer and it was a please meeting mr Firestone. Velvet merkin should be tasted when you find it available

Pouring at the Night of the Barrels on the Friday night of EBF 2012.  Pours a deep cola brown with a medium to large beige to tan head.  Wood, bourbon, vanilla and toast on the nose.  Medium bodied, soft and sweet, caramel.  Remarkably easy drinking.  Smooth, toast, and malt.  Soft caramel.  Long sweet malt and bourbon on the finish.

FoBAB 11- Pours a jet black with almost no head. Nose and taste were of an aged stout (somewhat subdued and faded) with a nice blend of oaky goodness. It was a solid beer, I enjoyed the fact that it was a lower abv offering on a high abv day. Not a game changer, but something I would buy off the shelf if it were bottled.

On nitro tap, not cask jason!,  at Maproom and poured into a tulip... Pours a deeper silky black hued elixir, darkly consistently throughout, and topped with a thin to medium creamy light khaki head that eventually reduces to a very thin film.  Appealing to say the least... Solid subdued bourbon with equalizing notes of vanilla and coconut. Sweet, silky, and alluring... Flavors continue on the same wavelength with sweeter cocoa bourbon nuttiness with a little coconut to go along with the aforementioned. A bit of residual sweetness involved but the flavors are favorable after all. Body is just shy of medium with a soft to mild level of carbonation. Glad to have tried.  Really solid aroma but the residual sweetness in the flavor left it lingering for too long though.

Cask... Dark brown, almost black, big creamy light tan head at first, fades quick to a ring only... Milky smooth bourbon nose, light roast, cream and nuts... Feel is great, light bitter cocoa nibs, vanilla, fudge... Excellent

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Found this note in an old stack of papers.  Tasted on draft in January 2010 at Sun Devil.  Pours deep, dark brown, with a red velvet cake tint peaking through, and an average beige head that slowly recedes to a thin collar of lace.  The nose is dominated by dark chocolate and roasted coffee malt, with  an underlying vanilla and coconut barrel aroma.  The flavor starts off with the lightly sweet vanilla, coconut, caramel whiskey, and milk chocolate up front, moving to the more roasty and lightly bitter dark chocolate and coffee notes.  The body is full with average carbonation and a long, coconut, vanilla, and lightly bitter roasted coffee finish.

Sampled on Tap at 1702, Tucson; March 2010
Arrives from the tap an opaque, dark color that shows a touch of clear red / brown hues when held up to the light. The head is quite wispy and seems a bit dark.  At first the aroma has a thin vanilla note to it as well as a roast grain aromatic.  Actually the aroma is really hard for me to smell, but as it warms I get hints of buttery oak and a hint of almost fruity tartness.
 
There is a hint of sweetness in the flavor (or is that vanillin) up front, but this dries out quite significantly as this rolls across the tongue. Vanillin lingers along with notes of dark chocolate, roasted grain and a hint of barrel-derived spiciness on the palate.  The mouthfeel is pretty creamy feeling, but it still remains light as this is definitely a beer to quaff a couple pints of.  The roast character dominates the flavor profile, but it is well balanced and keeps from being harsh, astringent, or acidic (which I find as common "flaws" in roasted beers).  This is really well balanced in the flavor; roast, sweeter malt character, vanillin and bittering notes all work together quite harmoniously.  The barrel is quite mellow actually, vanillin is here, as is an oak derived spiciness and a tannic quality in the finish, but I could almost be convinced that this was not barrel aged.
 
This is an awesome quaffing / session brew; it is full flavored, delicious and complex, too bad that this aroma comes off as being so muted (is it the glass, my nose, I dont know but I think it is actually just the beer).

Draft at Flannys.  Damn fine brew! Nearly a black pour, nice light brown head.  Tons of vanilla, chocolate, oak, bourbon, coconut in the nose.  Wonderful vanilla, coconut and bourbon hit first with a great chocolate note on the finish.  Man I would kill for bottles of this!

Draught. Pours a dark brown with a small offwhite head. Smells of dark dried berries, bourbon and perhaps some chocolate malt. Tastes of milk chocolate, red berries and a small hint of bourbon with minimal bitterness. Texture is very creamy. Carbonation is soft. Finish is dry. A very good beer.

Tap @ Holiday Ale Festival...  Wow oh wow! Certainly the buzz beer of the Fest but totally deserving of the buzz.  Deep, near black pour with a beige head.  Big whiskey and toasted caramel notes. Both in the aroma and flavor. Ashy grains. A hint of booziness towards the finish.

On tap with Carla at Portland Winter Ale Fest. Pours a thick dark brown with yellow/tan foam. Smells strongly of whiskey with hints of molasses. Tastes strongly of whiskey, but mellows nicely into a sweet chocolate. Described as "An abusive relationship", it beats you, but treats you nice after.

On tap at FW15 Release Party at Blue Palms. Pours with a black body with a small tan head. Aromas are of bourbon, oak, vanillin, cream soda, brown sugar, iodine, molasses and a big malty, toasted bread note. Flavors are of brown sugar, vanilla, barrel, marshmallow, and chocolate. Very clean, straight forward and tasty. Smooth, creamy, lightly warming with medium to low carbonation. I wish they would bottle this in six packs as well (I can dream, right?)!

On draft at the Bistro Barrel fest. One of the top three of the night. It pours dark brown with heavy roast and cream in the aroma. The flavor is roasted malt, nuts, ash, cocoa, light wood and astringency. Just a little bourbon without dominating the palate. Very nice and well done. The impy stouts are kicking butt at this fest!

Draft at FoBAB 9. Pours a deep brown/black with a tan head. Nose is really great. Lots of chocolate and coconut, toasted oats & roast. Pretty mellow in the nose. On tasting, its a pretty amazing little beast. Lots of chocolate and vanilla, enough bitterness to really tie it together and the hops are well faded in the background. Really clean and just and fantastic stout.

On tap (FoBAB 2011) : The aroma consists of chocolate, roast, faint burnt notes, vanilla, and oak.  Its a dark brown with some orange highlights and a small beige head.  The flavor starts with chocolate, caramel, vanilla, and light roast.  The finish is sweet with coconut and light vanilla.  Overall, its decent, but a little too much coconut for my liking.
On draft pour.  Pitch black with a tan head.  Bourbon nose, and light bourbon flavor.  Nice complex bbs.
Black with a fizzy tan head. Chocolate coffee and a hint of caramel aroma and taste with fairly subtle bourbon hiding on the back end.

Tasted alongside Parabola.  Opaque, fairly oakey, some applewood smoke?, well carbonated, less rich and less dried dark fruit and chocolate than Parabola.  Would very happily drink again, but prefer Parabola.
Sampled at Deconstructed event during LA Beer Week, very interesting beer.  Has the oaky and bourbony thing going on but it is also very dry.  I liked this one as much as the regular Velvet.

On tap, poured thick black with nice creamy tan head, aroma brought notes of lots of chocolate, toffee, coffee, bourbon, vanilla, some oats and burnt toast, and roast in there as well.  Really nice smelling, and the taste was the same and still smooth.  Big creamy chocolate, roast, coffee and toffee mixed with the slight vanilla and bourbon notes, finishing slightly bitter, nice and creamy on the palate.  Very good!

Reviewed from notes.

Pours a dark brown color with a thin tan head and a few spots of lacing.  Nice collar as it goes down.  The nose brings a good contingent of roast and chocolate alongside the really nice barrel notes.  Fantastic amount of bourbon plus some oak and vanilla.  The flavor brings smooth bourbon as well as oak, vanilla, chocolate, and moderate roast.  Medium body that is quite creamy with really nice barrel qualities.  Very, very well done.  Not surprising coming from Firestone.

On tap. Oatmeal stout aged in bourbon for a year. Pour is black tinted brown, spotty thin lacing, no head. Aromas of smoke, oats, toffee, juicy west coast hops. Taste is very floral for an oatmeal stout with just the right amount of roast. Taste is tons of chocolate and resinous hops. Finishes smooth as hell. So drinkable especially at 5.5%. Another awesome brew from David Walker.
On tap. Pours dark brown with a thin beige head and a chocolate and coffee aroma. There is a dry chocolate and cola flavor with a bourbon finish. Very tasty.

Just caught on about Merkin - note said Merkin: Draft at WCBF 08. Keg driven up the valley. Good show. Dark malt and chocolate aromas. Black color with a tan head. Fresh dark malt - smooth - with bourbon & oak notes. Quite a bit of bourbon. Finish is quite smooth. Just super excellent. When they ran out, and I really wanted more, they gave me the glassful that was on display. Over a hundred in the shade, but that beer which had stood out for several hours was still damn good.

Tap at Blind Lady.  Didnt quite notice this was a different version, until I bummed into someone who recognized me from when I used to frequent Lost Abbey.  This was definitely a smoother version than the original.  Bourbon really nicely blends on this one.

Pours opaque with a hint of brown. A tan head does not last too long.  Aromas of mostly chocolate and lots of coffee on the late nose. Viscous coating on the mouthfeel. Chocolate, coffee and vanilla dominate the palate. The bourbon barrel really mellows/balances this out, but doesnt impart much flavor. Some cola on the finish.

On draft at Firestone 14th party. Poured a dark black color with tan head. Mild roast and hint of oak in the aroma. Taste was very smooth and mild roast with hints of bourbon and a velvety texture. Very good and not overwhelming with the bourbon but not as roasty as regular.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2013 Draft at the Firestone 14 Release Party. Pure BA Merlin not the 20% BA blend. Nose is prominent bourbon with lots of chocolate and oaky vanilla.Pitch black with a small tan head. Flavor is a nice amount of bourbon, oak woodiness, and dark chocolate. The coffee I had noticed heavily in the regular blend was missing replaced with a nice dark chocolate flavor. 11/7/2010 9/4/9/4/18 4.4

Bomber from Country Club Liquors. Nose is oaky vanilla, light bourbon, chocolate, and a sweet candisugar note. Very dark clear brown with a medium tan head. Flavor is a silky smooth chocolate tinged with vanilla and slight bourbon. With the lower ABV it has no heat.
